Transcriber's note:
In the printed book, line numbering was determined by the physical
length of a line. Sometimes the numbered line was one or even two
lines above or below the nearest multiple of 10. Where a stanza ended
on a multiple of 10, the first line of the following stanza was
numbered instead. Line numbers have been regularized for this e-text.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Hrothgar, king of the Danes, lives happily and peacefully, and bethinks

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: him to build a glorious hall called Hart. But a little after, one

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Grendel, of the kindred of the evil wights that are come of Cain, hears

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the merry noise of Hart and cannot abide it; so he enters thereinto by

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: night, and slays and carries off and devours thirty of Hrothgar's

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: thanes. Thereby he makes Hart waste for twelve years, and the tidings of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: this mishap are borne wide about lands. Then comes to the helping of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Hrothgar Beowulf, the son of Ecgtheow, a thane of King Hygelac of the

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Geats, with fourteen fellows. They are met on the shore by the

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: land-warder, and by him shown to Hart and the stead of Hrothgar, who

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: receives them gladly, and to whom Beowulf tells his errand, that he will

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: help him against Grendel. They feast in the hall, and one Unferth, son

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: of Ecglaf, taunts Beowulf through jealousy that he was outdone by Breca

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: in swimming. Beowulf tells the true tale thereof. And a little after, at

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: nightfall, Hrothgar and his folk leave the hall Hart, and it is given in

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: charge to Beowulf, who with his Geats abides there the coming of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Grendel.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Soon comes Grendel to the hall, and slays a man of the Geats, hight

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Handshoe, and then grapples with Beowulf, who will use no weapon against

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: him: Grendel feels himself over-mastered and makes for the door, and

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: gets out, but leaves his hand and arm behind him with Beowulf: men on

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the wall hear the great noise of this battle and the wailing of Grendel.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: In the morning the Danes rejoice, and follow the bloody slot of Grendel,

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: and return to Hart racing and telling old tales, as of Sigemund and the

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Worm. Then come the king and his thanes to look on the token of victory,

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Grendel's hand and arm, which Beowulf has let fasten: to the hall-gable.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: The king praises Beowulf and rewards him, and they feast in Hart, and

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the tale of Finn and Hengest is told. Then Hrothgar leaves Hart, and so

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: does Beowulf also with his Geats, but the Danes keep guard there.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: In the night comes in Grendel's Mother, and catches up Aeschere, a thane

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: of Hrothgar, and carries him off to her lair. In the morning is Beowulf

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: fetched to Hrothgar, who tells him of this new grief and craves his

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: help.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Then they follow up the slot and come to a great water-side, and find

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: thereby Aeschere's head, and the place is known for the lair of those

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: two: monsters are playing in the deep, and Beowulf shoots one of them to

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: death. Then Beowulf dights him and leaps into the water, and is a day's

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: while reaching the bottom. There he is straightway caught hold of by

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Grendel's Mother, who bears him into her hall. When he gets free he

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: falls on her, but the edge of the sword Hrunting (lent to him by

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Unferth) fails him, and she casts him to the ground and draws her sax to

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: slay him; but he rises up, and sees an old sword of the giants hanging

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: on the wall; he takes it and smites off her head therewith. He sees

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Grendel lying dead, and his head also he strikes off; but the blade of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the sword is molten in his venomous blood. Then Beowulf strikes upward,

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: taking with him the head of Grendel and the hilts of the sword. When he

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: comes to the shore he finds his Geats there alone; for the Danes fled

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: when they saw the blood floating in the water.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: They go up to Hrothgar's stead, and four men must needs bear the head.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: They come to Hrothgar, and Beowulf gives him the hilts and tells him

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: what he has done. Much praise is given to Beowulf; and they feast

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: together.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: On the morrow Beowulf bids farewell to Hrothgar, more gifts are given,

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: and messages are sent to Hygelac: Beowulf departs with the full love of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Hrothgar. The Geats come to their ship and reward the ship-warder, and

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: put off and sail to their own land. Beowulf comes to Hygelac's house.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Hygelac is told of, and his wife Hygd, and her good conditions, against

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: whom is set as a warning the evil Queen Thrytho.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Beowulf tells all the tale of his doings in full to Hygelac, and gives

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: him his gifts, and the precious-gemmed collar to Hygd. Here is told of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Beowulf, and how he was contemned in his youth, and is now grown so

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: renowned.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Time wears; Hygelac is slain in battle; Heardred, his son, reigns in his

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: stead, he is slain by the Swedes, and Beowulf is made king. When he is

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: grown old, and has been king for fifty years, come new tidings. A great

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: dragon finds on the sea-shore a mound wherein is stored the treasure of

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: ancient folk departed. The said dragon abides there, and broods the gold

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: for 300 years.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Now a certain thrall, who had misdone against his lord and was fleeing

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: from his wrath, haps on the said treasure and takes a cup thence, which

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: he brings to his lord to appease his wrath. The Worm waketh, and findeth

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: his treasure lessened, but can find no man who hath done the deed.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Therefore he turns on the folk, and wars on them, and burns Beowulf's

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: house.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Now Beowulf will go and meet the Worm. He has an iron shield made, and

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: sets forth with eleven men and the thrall the thirteenth. He comes to

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the ness, and speaks to his men, telling them of his past days, and

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: gives them his last greeting: then he cries out a challenge to the Worm,

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: who comes forth, and the battle begins: Beowulf's sword will not bite on

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the Worm. Wiglaf eggs on the others to come to Beowulf's help, and goes

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: himself straightway, and offers himself to Beowulf; the Worm comes on

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: again, and Beowulf breaks his sword NÃ¦gling on him, and the Worm wounds

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Beowulf. Wiglaf smites the Worm in the belly; Beowulf draws his ax, and

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: between them they slay the Worm.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Beowulf now feels his wounds, and knows that he is hurt deadly; he sits

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: down by the wall, and Wiglaf bathes his wounds. Beowulf speaks, tells

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: how he would give his armour to his son if he had one; thanks God that

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: he has not sworn falsely or done guilefully; and prays Wiglaf to bear

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: out the treasure that he may see it before he dies.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
ARGUMENT
line: Wiglaf fetches out the treasure, and again bathes Beowulf's wounds;

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Beowulf speaks again, rejoices over the sight of the treasure; gives to

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Wiglaf his ring and his armour, and bids the manner of his bale-fire.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: With that he passes away. Now the dastards come thereto and find Wiglaf

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: vainly bathing his dead lord. He casteth shame upon them with great

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: wrath. Thence he sends a messenger to the barriers of the town, who

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: comes to the host, and tells them of the death of Beowulf. He tells

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: withal of the old feud betwixt the Geats and the Swedes, and how these,

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: when they hear of the death of the king, will be upon them. The warriors

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: go to look on Beowulf, and find him and the Worm lying dead together.

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Wiglaf chooses out seven of them to go void the treasure-house, after

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: having bidden them gather wood for the bale-fire. They shove the Worm

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: over the cliff into the sea, and bear off the treasure in wains. Then

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: they bring Beowulf's corpse to bale, and they kindle it; a woman called

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: the wife of aforetime, it may be Hygd, widow of Hygelac, bemoans him:

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: and twelve children of the athelings ride round the bale, and bemoan

Poem Title: ARGUMENT
line: Beowulf and praise him: and thus ends the poem.

line: Eanmund (149 [2610]), while in exile at the court of the Geats, was

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: slain by Weohstan, father of Wiglaf, and stripped of the armour given

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: him by his uncle, the Swedish King Onela. Weohstan "spake not about the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: feud, although he had slain Onela's brother's son," probably because he

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: was not proud of having slain an "exile unfriended" in a private

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: quarrel.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Ecglaf, father of Unferth, Hrothgar's spokesman (29 [499]).

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Ecgtheow (22 [373]), father of Beowulf the Geat, by the only daughter of

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Hrethel, king of the Geats. Having slain Heatholaf, a warrior of the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Wylfings, Ecgtheow sought protection at the court of the Danish King

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Hrothgar, who accepted his fealty and settled the feud by a

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: money-payment (27 [463]). Hence the heartiness of Beowulf's welcome at

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Hrothgar's hands.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Ecgwela. The Scyldings or Danes are once called "Ecgwela's offspring"

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: (99 [1710]). He may have been the founder of the older dynasty of Danish

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: kings which ended with Heremod.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Eofor (142, 167-9 [2485, 2963-2996]), a Geat warrior, brother of Wulf.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: He came to the aid of his brother in his single combat with the Swedish

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: King Ongentheow, and slew the king, being rewarded by Hygelac with the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: hand of his only daughter.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Eotens (61, 62, 66 [1072, 1088, 1141]) are the people of Finn, king of

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Friesland. In other passages, it is merely a name for a race of

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: monsters.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: FINN (61-7 [1068-1156]). The somewhat obscure Finn episode in _Beowulf_

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: appears to be part of a Finn epic, of which only the merest fragment,

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: called the _Fight at Finnsburg_, is extant. The following conjectured

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: outline of the whole story is based on this fragment and on the Beowulf

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: episode; Finn, king of the Frisians, had carried off Hildeburh, daughter

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: of Hoc, probably with her consent. Her father, Hoc, seems to have

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: pursued the fugitives, and to have been slain in the fight which ensued

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: on his overtaking them. After the lapse of some twenty years Hoc's sons,

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: HnÃ¦f and Hengest, are old enough to undertake the duty of avenging their

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: father's death. They make an inroad into Finn's country, and a battle

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: takes place in which many warriors, among them HnÃ¦f and a son of Finn,

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: are killed. Peace is then solemnly concluded, and the slain warriors are

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: burnt. As the year is too far advanced for Hengest to return home, he

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: and those of his men who survive remain for the winter in the Frisian

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: country with Finn. But Hengest's thoughts dwell constantly on the death

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: of his brother HnÃ¦f, and he would gladly welcome any excuse to break the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: peace which had been sworn by both parties. His ill-concealed desire for

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: revenge is noticed by the Frisians, who anticipate it by themselves

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: attacking Hengest and his men whilst they are sleeping in the hall. This

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: is the night attack described in the _Fight at Finnsburg_. It would seem

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: that after a brave and desperate resistance Hengest himself falls in

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: this fight at the hands of the son of Hunlaf (66 [1143]), but two of his

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: retainers, Guthlaf and Oslaf, succeed in cutting their way through their

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: enemies and in escaping to their own land. They return with fresh

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: troops, attack and slay Finn, and carry his queen Hildeburh back to the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Daneland.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Folkwalda (62 [1089]), father of Finn.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Franks (70, 165 [1210, 2911]). Hygelac, king of the Geats, was defeated

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: and slain early in the sixth century, in his historical invasion of the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Netherlands, by a combined army of Frisians, Franks, and Hugs.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Freawaru (116 [2022]), daughter of Hrothgar and Wealhtheow. Beowulf

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: tells Hygelac that her father has betrothed her to Ingeld, prince of the

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: Heathobards, in the hope of settling the feud between the two peoples.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: But he prophesies that the hope will prove vain: for an old Heathobard

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: warrior, seeing a Danish chieftain accompany Freawaru to their court

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: laden with Heathobard spoils, will incite the son of the former owner of

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: the plundered treasure to revenge, until blood is shed, and the feud is

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: renewed. That this was what afterwards befell, we learn from the Old

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
line: English poem _Widsith_. _See also_ ll. 83-5.

Poem Title: PERSONS AND PLACES
